title: U.S. stock indexes set to pause after records as investors assess jobless claims, GDP revision
text:
How stock benchmarks are trading

Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial AverageYMU21YM00 were trading 19 points higher at 35,379, a gain of 0.1%.

S&P 500 index futuresESU21ES00were off 5.15 points, or 0.1%, at 4,487.75.

Nasdaq-100 futures NQU21 NQ00 retreated 40.75 points, or 0.3%, at 15,323.50.

On Wednesday, the Dow DJIA rose 39.24 points, or 0.1%, to end at 35,405.50, supported by gains in financials, and rising to within 1% of its Aug. 16 record high; the S&P 500 index SPX closed at a record 4,496.19, and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP climbed 22.06 points, or 0.2%, closing at a record 15,041.86.

What's driving the market?

U.S. stocks looked vulnerable to a pullback after the major equity indexes climbed for at least four consecutive days, registering a series of records.

The Labor Department said first-time jobless claims rose 4,000 last week to 353,000, slightly above forecasts for a reading of 350,000 after dipping to a pandemic low in the previous week.

A second estimate of U.S. gross domestic product, the official scorecard of U.S. economic expansion, showed annualized growth of 6.6%, compared with an initial reading of 6.5%. Economists had looked for a revised rate of 6.7%.

Fed chair Powell will speak at 10 a.m. Eastern Friday at a Jackson Hole symposium of global central bankers that is being held virtually and could provide some guideposts for the timing and pace of the Fed's plans to scale back on crisis-era policy accommodations. However, expectations that Powell will use the venue as an opportunity to broach the subject of tapering have diminished since last week amid the spread of the highly transmissible delta variant of COVID-19.

Kansas City Fed President Esther George, in a Thursday television interview, said she backed tapering the central bank's asset purchases “sooner rather than later.”

The spread of the contagion has led Bank of America to lower its year-end forecast on the 10-year Treasury note TMUBMUSD10Y to 1.55%.

“We came into 2021 with a 10Y year-end target of 1.5% but subsequently revised higher to eventually above 2% after the Democratic clean sweep, vaccine progress and sharp upward revision of economic expectations from our U.S. economists. We now return nearly full circle,” wrote analysts led by Mark Cabana.

“We are forced to acknowledge that the delta variant has caused a considerable reassessment of the economic outlook as priced in by rates markets globally,” he wrote.

Federal regulators are likely to approve a COVID-19 booster shot for vaccinated adults starting at least six months after the previous dose rather than the eight-month gap they previously announced, The Wall Street Journal reported, as the Biden administration steps up preparations for delivering boosters to the public.

Which companies are in focus?

Lululemon Athletica Inc. LULU, +0.62% said Thursday that it will raise the minimum base pay for most of its North America employees to $15 or $17 per hour, depending on their role in the market.

Shares of XPeng Inc. XPEV fell 1.2% in premarket trading Thursday, after the China-based electric vehicle maker reported a wider-than-expected second-quarter loss but revenue that rose more than sixfold to top forecasts.

Salesforce.com Inc. CRM shares rose after the cloud-based customer-relationship management company hiked its forecast for the year yet again late Wednesday, following a strong quarter when it closed on its acquisition of Slack Technologies Inc.

Coty Inc. shares COTY rose 2.9% in premarket trade Thursday, after the cosmetics company beat revenue estimates for its fiscal fourth quarter after a strong performance in the Americas and China. 

What are other markets doing?

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 1.6 basis point to 1.358%. Yields and bond prices move in opposite directions.

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, rose 0.1%.

Oil futures pulled back after a three-day run of gains, with the U.S. benchmark CL00 down 1.1% at $67.58 a barrel. Gold futures GC00 edged 0.1% lower to trade at $1,789.90 an ounce.

In European equities, the Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP fell 0.3%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX was off 0.2%.

In Asia, the Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index HK:HSI ach fell 1.1%, while Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK rose 0.1%.
